Colin, thanks :) (although I didn't actually contribute to this achievement=
) Actually, there is a back story.  I went to grad school at UT Austin with=
 Shimon Whiteson, who is now an assistant professor at the University of Am=
sterdam (and who may still be reading this group).  It happens that his bro=
ther Daniel Whiteson is a physicist who I believe was working at Fermilab. =
 Daniel was therefore familiar with the deeper issues in the top quark prob=
lem, and Shimon came to realize through speaking to his brother that they n=
eeded some kind of learning technique.  I believe Shimon had the insight th=
at a non-supervised approach (i.e. something that does not require targets =
like backprop) could potentially use fitness to optimize for the kind of an=
swers that are really desired, rather than just for accuracy.  So for that =
purpose NEAT was a good fit.  

They ended up actually running some such ex=
periments and seeing that it seemed to work well.  Somehow, that idea did u=
ltimately become accepted enough at the accelerator that apparently the hun=
dreds of authors of that paper adopted it as the primary method for this pr=
oblem and it became a part of their methodology.  

I was surprised of cour=
se by how far it got.  Shimon has pointed out that maybe some other neuroev=
olution approach or even some other machine learning approach could also ha=
ve done well (although Fermilab did try several approaches that did not far=
e as well as NEAT at the time).  In a sense it may be luck for NEAT that NE=
AT happened to be what was on hand.  However, in any case, it is to NEAT's =
credit that it was indeed the approach used for this accomplishment.

ken

=

to NEAT in terms

at the back
> story is there - perhaps Aaltonen or one of the other authors=
 arived
> at the conclusion that they needed something akin to neuro evolut=
ion
> and discovered NEAT via a search. Or perhaps there was some connectio=
n
> at a cross discipline conference?
>

ons are in order.
